 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  India  for  the  Karnataka  State  Highway  Improvement  Project.  The  report  also  describes 
proposed technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building for Karnataka State Road Sector, and 
if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the 
Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
The  Karnataka  State  Highway  Improvement  Project  will  upgrade  about  615  kilometers 
2. 
(km)  of  state  highways  in  the  state  of  Karnataka  and  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  Public 
Works  Department  (PWD)  of  the  Government  of  Karnataka  (GOK)  to  develop,  operate,  and 
maintain  the  state  road  network.  Consulting  services  will  be  provided  to  supervise  the 
implementation of civil works and support the establishment and operation of the Planning and 
Road  Asset  Management  Centre  (PRAMC)  of  the  PWD.  Associated  TA  will  be  provided  to 
support  and  strengthen  the  PWD’s  capacity  in  asset  management,  road  safety,  and  private 
sector participation. Road improvement works will include the upgrading of existing roads to two 
lanes;  green-field  construction  of  bypasses;  strengthening  of  culverts  and  bridges;  and 
constructing new bridges, rail overbridges, and cross-draining structures. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

Under  the  India  country  partnership  strategy  (2009–2012), 2   the  Asian  Development 
3. 
Bank (ADB) supports all levels of the road sector development as a core infrastructure operation 
to facilitate sustainable economic growth. The project is consistent with the country partnership 
strategy’s  strategic  objectives  and  was  included  in  the  India  country  operations  business  plan 
(2011). Given the high level of project readiness, the processing of the project has been brought 
forward from 2011 to 2010.  
 
4. 
In  India,  road  transport  accounts  for  68%  of  freight  movement  and  87%  of  passenger 
traffic. The national highways and the secondary system are unable to cope with the rapid traffic 
growth;  freight  traffic  on  roads  has  increased by  about  12%  per  year and  passenger  traffic  by 
about 8% per year over the past decade. These trends have led to congestion, deterioration of 
roads,  and  increases  in  transport  costs.  State  highways  (the  secondary  road  system  in  India) 
link  national  highways  with  district  headquarters  and  important  towns.  The  secondary  system 
comprises about 13% of the road network and carries about 40% of traffic.  
 
5. 
The road network in Karnataka comprises 3,987 km of national highways, 22,078 km of 
state highways, 50,037 km of major district roads, and 147,212 km of village roads. There is an 
increasing  demand  for  road  transport  leading  to  capacity  constraints  on  the  existing  road 
network.  Specifically,  only  27%  of  state  highways  and  21%  of  major  district  roads  are 
considered to be in good condition, while 14% of state highways and 20% of major district roads 
are  in  poor  condition.  More  than  13,000  km  of  state  highways  are  already  experiencing 
congestion of various degree, with more than 7,800 km operating at the capacity limit. 
 
6. 
Apart  from  the  need  to  improve  road  infrastructure,  the  PWD,  which  is  in  charge  of 
overall road sector development and management, needs to build sustainable capacity in road

the road network.

institutional  strengthening.

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

8. 
The long-term impact of the project will be accelerated economic growth in the state of 
Karnataka.  The  immediate  project  outcome  will  be  more  efficient  and  sustainable  transport 
operations on the state highway network. 

C. 

Outputs 

9. 
Specific  outputs  will  include:  (i)  upgrading  of  about  615  km  of  priority  state  highways;  
(ii)  the  transformation  of  road  sector  planning,  programming,  and  policy  formulation  into  an 
objective,  data-driven,  and  sustainable  process;  (iii)  safer  roads;  and  (iv)  stronger  capacity  at 
the PWD for the operation, maintenance, and protection of road assets.

The project will add value to the current efforts of GOK to secure sustainable financing 
10. 
for  the  road  sector  through  the  establishment  of  the  State  Road  Fund.  It  will  establish  robust 
mechanisms  to  ensure  the  most  effective  use  of  funds  in  the  road  sector.  Specifically,  the 
project  will  provide  (i)  consulting  services,  tools    and  equipment  to  support  establishment  and 
operation of PRAMC and mainstream objective, data driven practices in the areas of strategic 
road policy and planning, programming, and road safety; (ii) equipment to improve the efficiency 
and quality of asset management; and (iii) equipment to implement traffic incident management 
systems on two pilot corridors, and to support the implementation of a pilot accident black spot 

 program.3  To  ensure  the  sustainability  and  quality  of  PRAMC  operations,  consulting  services 
will  be  provided  in  three  phases:  (i)  preparatory  (6  months),  including  developing  business 
processes,  operations  manuals,  and  supply  and  installation  of  systems  and  tools  required  for 
PRAMC  operations;  (ii)  operational  (2  years),  working  with  PRAMC  staff  on  day-to-day 
operations  and  conducting  training  in  apprenticeship  mode;  and  (iii)  standby  (6  months), 
including  supporting  PRAMC  on  as-needed  basis,  once  operations  are  fully  taken  over  by  its 
staff.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

14. 
The  GOK  acting  through  the  PWD  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  project.  The 
project implementation unit (PIU) will be a part of the PWD and will be the implementing agency 
for the project. The chief project officer assisted by the project director (chief engineer level) will 
be  responsible  for  the  day-to-day  supervision  of  the  project.  The  PIU  will  report  on  high-level 
matters to the secretary and principal secretary, PWD. The project director has been appointed 
as the highway authority by the GOK under the Karnataka State Highway Act and has adequate 
decision-making power to implement all preconstruction activities. The PIU has four field offices 
near  the  project  roads,  to  manage  the  contracts  for  civil  work  and  construction  supervision. 
Each field office is headed by an executive engineer managing three or four subdivision offices. 
Civil works will be supervised by a firm of construction supervision consultants to be recruited 
through international competitive bidding with quality- and cost-based selection (using a quality–
cost ratio of 75:25). The PIU will use the services of the project coordination consultant financed 
by the GOK resources to prepare designs, bidding documents, and support other project-related 
activities.

A. 

Technical 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

18. 
Project roads were selected following a full-scale feasibility study. All road designs have 
been completed, the economic evaluation has been updated, applications for obtaining statutory 
environmental  clearances  from  state  and  central  authorities  have  been  submitted  (clearances 
for  some  roads  have  already  been  received),  and  preconstruction  activities  have  started. 
Detailed  designs  have  incorporated  the  recommendations  of  a  road  safety  expert  and  will  be 
subjected to road safety audits by the construction supervision consultant, with substantial input 

  5

 

  6 

B. 

Economic 

from an international road safety expert. Road safety audits will also be conducted during and 
after construction. The PIU’s experience in implementing a World Bank-financed project,5 along 
with its demonstrated capacity to carry out project preparation and implementation, will help to 
ensure improved project readiness and mitigate the risk of delay. 

19. 
Selection  of  the  project  roads  combined  weighted  scores  for  economic  viability  with 
scores  derived  from  the  environmental  and  social  screening  exercises.  The  economic 
evaluation of the project followed the standard practice of comparing life cycle road agency and 
user costs with and without the project, using net present value with a 12% discount rate and 
the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) as decision criteria. The Highway Development and 
Management  (HDM-4)  system,  which  focuses  on  transport  cost  savings,  was  used  in  the 
analysis. The EIRR for the project is about 34.8% and ranges from 13.7% to 61.7% for each of 
the  project  corridors.  Overall,  the  project  has  a  high  EIRR,  satisfying  the  economic  efficiency 
criteria.  
 
20. 
The sensitivity of the EIRR for the project roads was analyzed with respect to changes in 
the  benefit  and  cost  streams.  The  following  sensitivity  test  cases  were  examined:  (i)  capital 
costs increase by 15%, (ii) benefits (vehicle operating costs and travel time savings) decrease  
by  15%,  (iii)  capital  costs  increase  by  15%  and  benefits  decrease  by  15%,  (iv)  time-related 
benefits are excluded, and (v) benefits to nonmotorized traffic are excluded. The results show 
that the quantified economic benefits are robust to various sensitivity tests. EIRRs for the project 
range from 24.6% in the worst case scenario to 34.8% in the base case scenario. All selected 
corridors have an EIRR above 12% in most sensitivity tests.6  

C. 

Governance 

Institutional  capacity.  The  PIU  was  established  in  2001  to  manage  a  World-Bank-
21. 
financed  project  over  2001–2007  (footnote  5)  and  has  developed  adequate  experience, 
qualifications,  and  capacity  to  manage  externally  funded  projects.  It  has  been  managing  the 
preparation  of  new  projects  for  external  financing  and  is  using  the  services  of  the  project 
coordination  consultant  to  prepare  designs,  bidding  documents,  and  support  other  project-
related activities. Civil works will be supervised by a firm of construction supervision consultants.  
 
22. 
Financial  management.  The  PIU  has  demonstrated  adequate  capacity  to  handle 
financial  management  of  externally  funded  projects.  In  June  2010,  it  underwent  a  financial 
management assessment in accordance with ADB’s guidelines.7 The overall inherent risk was 
estimated as negligible and the overall control risk was estimated as moderate. A set of actions 
to mitigate the risks was identified. GOK has committed to implement all actions identified. By 
April 2011, before the start of the project, GOK  will start a three-tier audit system, including (i) a 
pre-audit  within  the  PIU,  (ii)  a  quarterly  internal  audit  by  chartered  accountant,  and  (iii)  a 
statutory audit by the comptroller and auditor general of India.8

Karnataka  has  a  population  of  53  million,  5.13%  of  India’s  population.  The  state’s 
25. 
population  density  is  275  per  km2  compared  with  the  national  figure  of  324.  About  66%  of 
Karnataka’s population lives in rural areas.9  
 
Agriculture is the mainstay of the state. Cultivators and agricultural laborers form about 
26. 
56%  of  the  workforce.  Households  engaged  in  agricultural  labor  account  for  40%  of  the  total 
population in rural Karnataka, while self-employed agricultural workers constitute 38%. In urban 
Karnataka, the regular wage or salary earning class constitutes the largest occupational group.  
 
27. 
At  focus  group  discussions  during  the  poverty  and  social  assessment,  communities 
looked  forward  to  the  better  access  and  enhanced  mobility  the  project  will  bring.  Better 
connections  will 
local  government  and 
development agency offices, health centers, schools, colleges, and market places. Better roads 
will  also  improve  social  networking.  In  addition  to  the  longer  term  positive  impact  on  poverty 
reduction,  the  project  will  also  have  a  short-term  impact,  as  the  rural  poor  will  be  hired  for 
construction, tree planting, and routine maintenance work. These opportunities will increase the 
earnings of the poor, who now depend largely on occasional and uncertain employment. 
 
28. 
The  project  will  offer  new  economic  and  employment  opportunities  by  providing  better 
links  to  markets,  production  centers,  and  other  areas  with  economic  opportunities.  The  rural 
population will be able to transport produce more quickly and to increase profit margins as they 
will no longer depend solely on local markets and middlemen. 
 
Gender. The gender development index  10 in Karnataka (0.637) is much higher than the 
29. 
national figure (0.609). Karnataka ranks 6 among the 15 major states in gender development. 
Women  are  mainly  involved  in  household  work,  cultivation,  and  other  agricultural  activities, 
including  some  employment  in  government  and  the  private  sector.  Their  use  of  roads  ranges 
from  day-to-day  household  activities  to  economic  activities  such  as  those  connected  with 
agriculture and marketing. Improvements to roads and better connections to the main network 
will  improve  access  for  women  and  children  to  social  services,  markets,  work  place,  higher 
levels of schooling, health facilities, and employment opportunities. Travel time savings due to 
improved road conditions will result in more time spent on productive activities, health care, and 
self development.

HIV  and  AIDS.  Karnataka  is  one  of  four  large  southern  India  states  with  a  relatively 
30. 
advanced HIV epidemic. The adult HIV prevalence in several districts has exceeded 1% for the 
past  9  years.  As  a  part  of  the  National  AIDS  Control  Program  of  the  National  AIDS  Control 
Organization, Karnataka has been conducting HIV sentinel surveillance since 1998. According 
to national family health survey, 0.69% of women (age 15-49 years) and men (age 15-54 years) 
in Karnataka are HIV positive. HIV prevalence among men is 0.85% and HIV prevalence among 
women is 0.54%. 
 
The detailed poverty and social assessment study done during project preparation does 
31. 
not  anticipate  a  rise  in  the  incidence  of  HIV  and  AIDS  as  a  result  of  the  project.  The  Health 
Department  and  the  Karnataka  State  AIDS  Control  Society  are  already  carrying  out  state, 
district,  and  block  level  campaigns  to  increase  awareness  of  the  disease.  In  addition,  the  PIU 
and  NGOs  implementing  resettlement  plans  will  involve  the  Karnataka  State  AIDS  Control 
Society  and  other  local  health  agencies  in  social  awareness  programs  (on  various  subjects, 
including HIV and AIDS) in the project areas. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

32. 
Environmental  impact.  The  project  is  classified  category  B  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). Initial environmental examinations were therefore prepared 
for  all  project  roads,  including  the  rail  overbridges.  The  main  environmental  concerns  with 
respect  to  this  project  are  occupational  and  community  health  and  safety,  traversed  notified 
forestlands, and the substantial number of old trees to be cleared along the right of way. 
 
Occupational  and  community  health  and  safety  will  be  addressed  through  temporary 
33. 
traffic management plans for work zones, which will be subject to road safety audits. Workers 
will receive mandatory safety training and be provided with personal protective gear. Emergency 
health care will be available and health information will be disseminated. All notified traversed 
forestlands were established by the government for reforestation and rehabilitation of degraded 
lands;  none  are  natural  or  critical  habitats  for  biodiversity.  A  memorandum  of  agreement  has 
been  signed  between  the  PIU  and  the  Forest  Department  on  afforestation  of  degraded 
forestlands  and  community  forestry.  The  number  of  old  trees  (e.g.,  acacia  and  ficus)  to  be 
cleared has been minimized through road alignments, without negatively affecting road safety, 
although the species are not on the endangered list and do not have nationally protected status. 
This approach has enabled about 800 trees with girths exceeding 30 centimeters to be saved. 
The  mandatory  compensatory  plantation  providing  for  planting  of  two  trees  for  every  one  tree 
cleared  was  observed  in  the  environment  management  plans.  No  tree  cutting  will  be  allowed 
without prior clearance from the Forest Department. Compensatory plantation will be carried out 
by  the  Forest  Department  on  behalf  of  the  PIU.  The  PIU  will  coordinate  with  the  Forest 
Department  to  ensure  that  roadside  plantations  will  not  interfere  with  vehicle  travel  and  road 
maintenance, will not cover signals and signs, and will not affect sight distances. PIU will submit 
to ADB progress reports on compensatory plantation twice a year. The PIU will be responsible 
for implementing the environmental management plan (EMP) and will monitor the compliance of 
contractors  with  the  EMP.  It  will  ensure  the  grievance  redress  mechanism  is  implemented 
through the dedicated EMP implementation unit. Progress reports on the implementation of the 
EMP will be submitted to ADB twice a year. 
 
34. 
Land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  The  project  is  categorized  as  category  A  in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Separate  resettlement  plans  have  been 
prepared  for  each  project  road  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and 
relevant national and state laws and regulations. 

  
35. 
Complete details of compensation rates for the loss of land and structures, assisting with 
shifting,  and  other  income  restoration  assistance  are  provided  in  the  entitlement  matrix  of  the 
resettlement  plans, 11  which  also  include  additional  support  for  affected  people  belonging  to 
vulnerable groups. Consultations with displaced persons, including on issues related to the land 
acquisition and compensation process, were undertaken during preparation of the resettlement 
plans.  Resettlement  plans  are  disclosed  to  the  public  through  the  ADB  website.  If  during 
detailed design and implementation any modification is required, or if there is an additional land 
requirement, or if involuntary resettlement impacts are identified, a related resettlement plan will 
be prepared or an original plan will be modified in accordance with the applicable laws referred 
to  in  the  original  resettlement  plan.  Prior  approval  by  ADB  will  be  obtained  before  further 
implementation of the relevant section of the project road takes place. 
 
36. 
Impact  on  indigenous  peoples. The project is classified under category C for impact 
on  indigenous  people.  The  project  area  has  no  demarcated  area  for  indigenous  people.  The 
poverty  and  social  assessment  revealed  no  adverse  impact  on  indigenous  groups  within  the 
area of influence of the subprojects. However, if any adverse impacts on indigenous people are 
identified  during  design  or  implementation,  an  indigenous  peoples  plan  will  be  prepared  in 
accordance with the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. This will be approved by ADB before 
the  award  of  any  related  civil  works  contract, and  implemented  before  commencement  of  civil 
works  on  the  relevant  section  of  the  project  road.  Any  subsequent  updating  of  the  indigenous 
peoples plan will require prior ADB approval before any further implementation of the relevant 
section of the project road.
